PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who has lived in Western Canada will have exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer. If so, don't worry about leaving blank spaces.

Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer:

- All Questionnaires
- Pioneer diet
- Pioneer schools
- Pioneer churches
- Pioneer recreation and social life
- Pioneer farming experiences
- Pioneers in Saskatchewan
- Pioneer health and housing

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Provincial Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our province. Please send your completed questionnaires to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and places names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name: John F. Isherwood
2. Your address: South Riverton, Quebec
3. Date: January 19, 1955
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Stafford, Kansas, U.S.A.
5. What was your father's name and occupation?
   - Fred Pratt Isherwood — Farmer
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): March, 1905
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible:
   - Kansas and Nebraska, 1895 to 1903
   - Arizona, 1903 to 1905
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.):
   - Nine years
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   - Came along with parents
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?):
    - Rather learned through government advertising or from homesteads
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? They thought we were on the wrong track for sure.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)? Covered wagon and rail road.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? Milestone, Sask.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? Father and Uncle homesteaded at Lathford, Sask., one mile east.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan. Marietta, Yarn, Wadena, Redwington, Ogema, Regina, Earl Grey.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came? Father farmed in Kansas and OK1 homesteaded. Farmed in Saskatchewan. Later I did Highway construction in Saskatchewan.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

They thought we were on the wrong track for sure.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

13. What means of transportation did you use?

14. What incidents of the journey west do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other experiences, etc.)

Primarily of the cold rains while living in tents in the month of March at Milestone, Sask., while waiting for our settlers effects to come to Canada by freight, consisting of camping outfits, wagons, furniture, horses, etc.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

Milestone, Sask.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Father and Uncle homesteaded at Lafortune, Sask. on a third section.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Watrous, Sask., Wadena, Sask., Regina, Sask., Pearl Creek, Sask., Melfort, Sask.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?

Father farmed in Kansas and Oklahoma—farmed in Saskatchewan. Later I did highway construction in Sask.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West, tell when they came and where they settled.

Father and Mother, one brother [so and so] of sister's marriage all came in 1903 and settled at Lajord.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to recount?

There are many. I have written my reminiscences of early experiences for Mr. [name of person] and they have been published in various newspapers.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

I traveled by horseback or buggy in those early years to Pleaton to visit [name], [name] and cousins, (distances of about two to five miles). If you can find some real old time humorists as were then in existence around Regina and district, try riding in a lumber wagon for a distance of one hundred yards, then just imagine a trip of several miles or thirty miles as was the case on our first trip from Missouri to the [name] district which later became part of Saskatchewan.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

Pather and Mother, one brother two uncles, sisters' families, etc., came in 1903 and settled at Lajord.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

There are many. I have written up my experiences and will send copies of them to you if you will let me know what you want.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) how often? How far? by what means of travel?

Often traveled by wagon, horseback or mule. In later years to Nelson to visit Aunt, Uncle, Nephew and cousins. (All stories of about two or three miles). If you can find some old old time humorists as were the In extenso around Barrie and district try riding in a lumber wagon for a distance of one hundred yards, then just imagine a trip of several miles or thirty miles as was the case on our first trip from Waterloo to the skid lot, which later became known as the town of Nelson.
25. When was the first car used in the community?
   About 1909 or 1910.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, whom did you buy it from? That makes?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   Seven miles east.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   New town of La Jolla—1904

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   About once a week the first summer.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
   About 1906 or 1907

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues?
   What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.
   About 1904

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   1913—A company formed at La Jolla at the time.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   The idea of the grom folks wasn't believe to settle permanently.
25. When was the first car used in the community?
   About 1909 or 1910.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   Seven miles

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better names of travel, etc.)
   New town of Leford—1904

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   About once a week the first summer.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
   About 1906 or 1907

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues?
   What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.
   About 1904

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   1913—A company formed at Leford at the time.

33. When you came to Sebasticook the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   The idea of the stony folks was I believe to settle permanently.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?
Some moved on to newly opened up homestead territory. Some returned to the U.S.A., later returned to continue with their homestead duties.

35. Did many people move away during the 1920's? Did many return?
I do not believe that many left the Lajord or Rioton district.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.
My father, Alfred Frank Isherwood was Secretary-Treasurer of Prairie Flower School District for many years from its beginning in 1904.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.)
Father, Alfred Frank Isherwood was first to own a gasoline tractor in the district, possibly first in the Province. A Hart-Parr 22-45 about April, 1907.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given, date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).
1- Alfred Frank Isherwood, -- Farmer.
2- Prairie Flower School District No. 020, at Lajord.
Two names submitted by my father were, Wild Rose and Prairie Flower. Prairie Flower was chosen as there was already one school district by the name Wild Rose. I think the meaning of the name is obvious.
Date of adoption I believe was 1904.
5.

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

Some moved to need land, opened up homesteads, homesteaded land, etc. Others returned to the U.S., A. L. Isherwood moved to Canada with their homestead until 1914.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

I do not know how many left, but I know that many returned.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organization, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

My father, Al Fred Frank Isherwood was Secretary-Treasurer of the Pine River School District for many years, commencing in 1904.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were interested in doing something in the district meeting, it here, giving dates wherever possible.

Such as owning the first automobile, combining, organizing the first lodge, etc.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.)

Give: (1) name and occupation of person engaging place-name; (2) origin and meaning of the name; (3) date of its adoption; (4) any changes in names since the first name was given; data and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

1. Al Fred Frank Isherwood - Formerly known as "Old Town," now called "New Town." My father named it after himself, Al Fred Frank Isherwood.

2. Pine River School District No. 999 at Latorre - Formerly known as "Pine River School District No. 999." My father named it after the river which flows through the school district. The name was changed to "Pine River School District No. 999" by the Board of Education in 1904.
39. Questions regarding historical source material:
Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, minute books of community organizations? (Please describe).
My own result answers—read stored at Archives Division of the Legislative Library.

A neighbor here has old photographs of Riel and other persons or the North West Rebellion, and an old photograph of the shell on which he brought his horse from Regina after sending off the North West Mounted Police during the Rebellion. This man is one of the oldest surviving members of the North West Mounted Police and is a fine old gentleman, 92 years old, and in good health for his age. Would you save the person who took them either story from him while he is still living?

Or have you any old maps or plans of the province? If so, please send them to the Provincial Archivist for copying.

(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, Regina, or the Archives Office at the University in Saskatoon?

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?
The most important change of course is in the number of inhabitants. Improvement of the same. I believe he had more to do with the prosperity of the community than anything else.

Please give the names and addresses of other pioneers who could answer this questionnaire.

Mr. Joseph A. Connel, Lethbridge, Sask.
Mr. Elmo Hanson, Lethbridge, Sask.
Mr. Frank Binnie, East Grey, Sask.

If someone else has filled in this questionnaire for you, please have this person give name and address here!
6.

39. Questions regarding historical source material:
Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, old books of community organizations, old newspapers, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences? (Quarterly)

My own reminiscences—registered at Oxford University or the Legislative Library.

A neighbor here has old photographs of a Real estate agent. To him from England a letter regarding the North West Mounted Police during the Rebellion, written by a man who was one of the chief surviving members of the North West Mounted Police. He is now 85 years old and lives in good health. Try his story. Would you give the person who owns them either story from him when he was younger?

Q. How can you get copies of these stories?
(1) by writing to the Provincial Archivist for copyright,........
(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, Regina, or the Archives Office at the University in Saskatoon.

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, share they live and occupations.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

The most important change of course is in the number of inhabitants. The prosperity of the community than any other also.

Please give the names and addresses of other pioneers who could answer this questionnaire.

Mr. Joseph A. Connel, Oxford, Sask.
Mr. Elmo H. Hansen, Oxford, Sask.
Mr. Frank Rimbey, East Grey, Sask.
